Message.Title: Arkansas refuses to cave to insanity.... so far
Message.Msg: STUTTGART, AR - No guns on campus is the decision for the University of Arkansas Board of Trustees. The panel voted this morning at Phillips Community College in Stuttgart (photo below) to opt out of Act 226 and not allow faculty/staff to carry concealed handguns on campus. The issue has been debated for months at universities across Arkansas. So far, all of them have voted to opt out of concealed handguns in classrooms and will keep the security in the hands of those wearing a badge.

Message.Title: CONFIRMED: Fox News Hack James Rosen Is A Political Operative, Not A Journalist
Message.Msg: Last edited Fri May 24, 2013, The First Amendment holds a place of unique reverence in the hearts of Americans. Rather than focusing on a single issue, its authors packed it with critical constraints on the federal government that encompass rights pertaining to speech, association, religion, and the press. It is a mouthful of freedom that justifiably deserves special attention. However, like everything in the Constitution, it is not absolute and it requires interpretation to be understood and implemented. With regard to recent events concerning Fox News, and its alleged reporter James Rosen, the question as to whether there was a violation of the First Amendment’s freedom of the press has roiled the media and spurred condemnation from across the political spectrum. However, no matter what one thinks about the propriety of a government agency examining the phone records of a purported journalist, James Rosen does not deserve to regarded as one. In the government’s affidavit supporting their request for a search warrant, a passage in the document reveals that Rosen had stepped far outside the boundaries of journalism. His activities were those of a political operative with a specific agenda that was openly hostile to the official foreign policy of the United States. And Rosen pursued that agenda with an intent to obtain classified materials that he knew was impermissible for him to possess.

Message.Title: GOP assault on women continues
Message.Msg: Eight Men (NO WOMEN) Consider House Bill To Restrict Women's Reproductive Rights Thu May 23, 2013, An all-male panel of House lawmakers considered a bill on Thursday that would ban abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy across the United States, without exceptions for rape, incest or health of the mother. The House Judiciary Subcommittee on the Constitution, led by the bill's sponsor, Rep. Trent Franks (R-Ariz.), has no female members.

Message.Title: GOP assault on students intensifies
Message.Msg: House Republicans Destroy the GOP by Voting to Raise Student Loan Interest Rates (Politicus USA) By a vote of 221-198, House Republicans continued to destroy their party by passing a bill that would raise student loan rates. Nine Republicans voted against the bill, and two Democrats voted for it. House Republicans tried to disguise their plan to raise student loan interest rates as saving the student loan program by making it a part of the “free market.” What House Republicans passed is a variable rate scheme where a student’s loan rate would be reset every year, so that the loan rate the student paid as a freshman would likely increased each year until they graduated.

Message.Title: Obamacare Will Be A Debacle — For Republicans
Message.Msg: The Affordable Care Act, aka Obamacare, is a policy Rube Goldberg device — instead of doing the simple, obvious thing, which would just be to insure everyone, it basically relies on a combination of regulations and subsidies to rope, coddle, and nudge us into a rough approximation of a single-payer system. There were reasons for this, of course, mainly political...Still, the question is whether this cobbled-together system will work, and there have been many conservatives rubbing their hands with glee over the prospect of failure. Whoops. We won’t really know how Obamacare works until it has been in operation for a while; but we do know that essentially the same system has been running in Massachusetts since 2006, and is doing pretty well. The question, then, is whether other states that don’t have MA’s initial advantages — especially an already low uninsurance rate and an already operating system of community rating — can make this thing work. The big fear has been of sharply rising premiums as insurers are required to cover people with preexisting conditions. And the biggest test case was always going to be California.

Topic.Title: Obamacare Will Be A Debacle — For Republicans

Message.Msg: Well, the preliminary numbers for CA are in — and they’re looking very good, with costs coming in below expectations. At this point, it looks as if this thing is indeed going to work. And think about the political dynamics. Because the Supreme Court decided to let states opt out of the Medicaid expansion, some states — notably Texas — will have a pretty dysfunctional version of Obamacare in 2014, although even those systems will provide significant benefits to many people. Still, the whole political calculus was supposed to be that Republicans in red states could point to the horrors of Obamacare and ride them to political victory. Instead, it looks as if we’re going to see blue-state residents reaping the benefits of a functional health care system, while red-state residents are denied many of those benefits, for what looks like no better reason than mean-spirited spite — because what’s going on is, indeed, mean-spirited spite. Paul Krugman

Topic.Title: Special Prosecutor Inevitable

Message.Msg: Oh boy, you managed to jam 2 significant misapprehensions into one little post. Biddermon's right if a significant number of people think like you do this will be a show. "Republicans" don't DO things for the reasons you've been indoctrinated into thinking. Therefore your predictions of their actions are all but worthless. If they see the administration as taking a partizan stance as regards to these investigations then they WILL request a special prosecutor, just as they would if it were a Republican President stonewalling them. The difference is that those Republicans about whom there's anything interesting to find usually resign first, a sort of party ethics policy long in place, sometimes ignored, but seldom unignored by the offender when its in force. I guess the difference is for Democrats is when they think they've exhausted their options and how much damage they're willing to do to their party on the way. I don't see a huge amount of restraint on the right when they think they've really got a bone though, and calling a special prosecutor is something that is ENTIRELY possible from the House. Even if calling it a bone and finding out all they've dug up is a stick makes them look bad, smelling a bone and not TRYING to dig it up, only to have someone else dig it up triumphantly later, well . . . that couldn't be tolerated. Call it contrasting viewpoints on the lessor of two evils. Republicans almost ALWAYS prefer the evil they know to the one they don't, regardless of what they're called, sometimes showing a regrettable lack of foresight. Other times that caution pays off well. It among other things kept us out of European arguments after the civil war, following the SAME basic foreign policies in that regard as the Democratic party had before it, until finally being pushed into WWI, costing the Republicans the White House they'd dominated since Lincoln.

Topic.Title: How Etrade is compared to AMTD, which way under performing the market availability.

Message.Msg: Er, when the company isn't a market maker in its own stock (that's probably a conflict of interest, though if I was Apple I'd probably use my cash to do it if it wasn't) I don't see how you can blame the executives when it doesn't trade at full market value for any period. Markets are markets, and DEMAND based around a certain bracket of value. At this time eTrade is traveling the low end of that bracket, but given its a viable growing ongoing business in a rebounding real estate market, that will at some point turn around and become a non-issue, making this a GREAT long term buy right now. It's at least 1/3 to 2/5 of my portfolio value. Somewhere in that area. Very minimal risk baring a depression that plunges the entire nation into poverty, in which case its STILL probably a good long term hold.
